name.value: GameDisk Die interaktive Quiz-Show für Kinder

item.description:
Die interaktive Quiz-Show Junior verison.
With the DVD and a gimmick called GameDisk one can play solitaire or up to 6 players can play the interactive quiz show, provided one has a DVD player or a computer. Per player one needs one GameDisk or an answer pad. or 10 Quiz rounds can be chosen, each round has 5 games and each game asks 6 questions. For each question one decides on an answer and uses the button of the GameDisk or marks the pad. The DVD provides a control code after each game, with this code the Gamedisk can tell the number of correct answers given. The player with the most correct answers at the end of 5 rounds wins the game. Edition without cards.

'Bomber über England' (Bombers over England) is like a pinball game that featured a map of England. The map contained holes in the location of key cities such as London, Liverpool, Birmingham and Newcastle, as well as points representing shipping targets in the North Sea.

Players shoot spring-driven metal balls representing "bombs" at these targets and are awarded points for hitting the enemy targets. Players are awarded a maximum 100 points for landing either on London or on the home base of the British fleet at Scapa Flow. Other cities and shipping targets are worth between 20 and 70 points. The game was clearly published during the "Phony War" period of late 1939/early 1940, since Calais in France is also worth 100 points, but neutral Amsterdam and Brussels score -80 points each (and hitting Germany is -100).

As with many games published during the Nazi regime, it was pure propaganda intended to focus players on supporting the war.

For the basic game players look at the movie from DVD and then play the game, they roll the die, draw and answer a question at the current field. Player gets chips for correct answers. Who has 8 chips first, wins.

Learning game with the DVD to learn the many interesting things about the airport and the aircraft are modern, from the perspective and experience of a child. 
Players look at the movie and then play the game, they roll the die, draw a card and answered a question at the current field, Player gets chips for correct answers. Who has 8 chips first, wins.

Learning game with the DVD to learn the many interesting things about the Fire Department, from the perspective and experience of a child. 
Players look at the movie and then play the game, they roll the die, draw a card and answered a question at the current field, Player gets chips for correct answers. Who has 8 chips first, wins.

Scénario is a game about producing movies. It is a trivia game with set collection and negotiation elements

The players' goal is to make and publish movies. Movies are made by collecting a set of matching Actors, Title, Director and Producer cards as well as enough money to produce the movie. Money and cards are collected by moving on the gameboard and answering movie-related questions. A player can only have one card of each type in hand, so if additional cards are collected (for example a second Director card), they can be either discarded or traded with the other players.

Movement on the board uses a roll-and-move mechanic, with a few tweaks, like no "reroll" spaces, and several spaces allow the player to move her game piece anywhere she wants on the board. At first players only have access to the board spaces that allow them to collect cards or money (provided they correctly answer a question). Once a player has at least produced at least one movie, she gains access to all of the gameboard, including spaces which allow players to collect cash from their produced movies.

Once a player has made more movies than other competitors, she can win the game by going to the "Palme d'Or" space and answering a special question. End of game questions are designed to be more difficult.

Scénario won the 1989 "As d'Or" for best simulation game at the Cannes international games festival.

Game description from the publisher:

Waterdeep, the City of Splendors – the most resplendent jewel in the Forgotten Realms, and a den of political intrigue and shady back-alley dealings. In this game, the players are powerful lords vying for control of this great city. Its treasures and resources are ripe for the taking, and that which cannot be gained through trickery and negotiation must be taken by force!

In Lords of Waterdeep, a strategy board game for 2-5 players, you take on the role of one of the masked Lords of Waterdeep, secret rulers of the city. Through your agents, you recruit adventurers to go on quests on your behalf, earning rewards and increasing your influence over the city. Expand the city by purchasing new buildings that open up new actions on the board, and hinder – or help – the other lords by playing Intrigue cards to enact your carefully laid plans.

During the course of play, you may gain points or resources through completing quests, constructing buildings, playing intrigue cards or having other players utilize the buildings you have constructed. At the end of 8 rounds of play, the player who has accrued the most points wins the game.

item.description: The famous Monopoly now themed around Swabia in southwest Germany. Monopoly game play, only the theme is - like all themed Monopoly versions - resembles the new region.

name.value: Mi primer inglés: O meu primeiro inglês

item.description: To make the first words in english very easy, children play the well-known games of lotto or memory or bingo and use 36 picture cards showing english words belonging to one of 9 groups: Family, animals, body, toys, at home, at school, food+drinks, clothes and seasons. Speaking and hearing in this game are very important so a grown-up who speaks English should be present during play.

Your day job fiercely competes for every bit of free time and patience with the demands of family life and the lure of hobbies. The consequences of wild nightlife, sloth and other sins are barely balanced by the occasional burst of sport activity and more-or-less random jabs at a healthy lifestyle.

Sound familiar? No, we are not talking about your life, but about what you are up against in Infarkt ("Heart Attack"), a party game in which you want to be the last one left at the party – literally.

Each player has an individual player board on which she'll track her blood pressure, depression, lung health, weight and so on. Everyone starts out as healthy as possible, with some money ($1) in the pocket, too. Each round, a number of event cards equal to one more than the number of players is revealed. In turn, each player will choose an event card and suffer the effects of that card, moving her health indicators as needed. Did you run out of gas? Or have a bout of diarrhea? Man, life sucks.

Players then simultaneously deploy three action markers to indicate where they plan to go that day: the supermarket, the office, a pharmacy, a flea market, the gym, and so on. In turn order, players then execute all three of their actions in whatever order they desire. Maybe you'll hit the office to earn money, but at the cost of having your depression grow more intense. A trip to the supermarket will let you buy food, which you can then eat later at home or give to your neighbors who come to the party you throw. Force them to eat cake and get fat! If you have extra money on hand, you might want to visit the pharmacy to buy drugs; you never know what the pharmacist will give you, but if you don't like it (or the food you've acquired), you can hit the flea market to swap food and drugs – and maybe pick up some change in the bargain.

At the end of the round, you check your health levels to see whether your body is deteriorating without you even knowing. Get too depressed, for example, and the depression only gets worse; high blood pressure can affect your blood cholesterol level, and vice versa. If a health indicator rises to the tombstone at the top of the column, you've partied your last and are now out of the game. (Everyone else has to chip in for the funeral, suffering depression if they can't afford to pony up for a decent burial for a good friend like you.) The last player alive in the game wins and dances on the graves of everyone else!

item.description:
Kids' Trivia includes 1,500 questions on Art, Science, TV, Movies, History, Famous people, Superheroes, Comics, and Music (in large, easy to read print).

Recommended for kids Ages 7 upwards.

item.description:
• Bet: Bet secretly on the winning post order of the three first horses.

• Bluff: Fool your opponents by moving advancing any horse you like, without showing your real intentions.

• Win: Swipe the stake! You receive two points for each horse in the right place and ten points for guessing the three first horses in the right order at the post. The first player to score 16 points wins!

In Jumpy Jack, you'll need to use the luck of the die roll and bluffing to get around the four hurdles that can stop or delay your horses – or completely eliminate them from the race. When played with large groups, players compete in teams, requiring you to think like your teammate in order to get those horses across the line...

item.description:
Yam Master combines the dice-combination game play of Yahtzee and other such designs with a competition for prime spots on the game board in order to create rows of tokens.

On a turn, a player rolls the five dice, setting aside any he wishes, then rolls up to two more times with dice set aside in the first round being available for reroll on the third throw. After his final throw, the player can place one of his tokens on the game board on any space for which his dice-combination qualifies. The possible combinations are:


 Three of a kind ("Square" 1-6): at least three dice with the same number (Square 2 = at least three dice with a "2")
 Full House ("Full"): three dice of a kind and two dice of a kind (not necessarily different)
 Four of a kind ("Carré"): at least four dice with same number
 Five of a kind ("Yam"): five dice with the same number
 Straight ("Suite"): 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 or 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
 ≤8: when the sum of all dice does not exceed 8
 One shot ("Sec"): one of the above figures, except 3 of a kind, in the first throw
 Challenge ("Défi"): before the second throw, the player places a bet and successfully attains on of the figures above, except 3 of a kind, within the second or third throw. He must not bet on a specified figure.


Note that a "Yam" is also a "Square", a "Full", and a "Carré"; the player may choose which combination space he wants to cover with his token. Covering a space with a token is optional.

Instead of placing a token after a Yam, the player may remove one of the opponent's tokens from the game board.

The game ends either when one player creates a row of five tokens on the game board – winning the game instantly – or when a player places his twelfth token on the board; in the latter case, players score two points for each four-in-a-row created with their tokens and one point for each three-in-a-row, with the winner being decided on points.

item.description:
User review: Football-themed rummy variant.

Each player is dealt six cards. In turn, each player repleshes one's hand to six and draws an extra card, then plays a card or discards a card. Some cards allow a player to force an opponent to miss turns or forfeit cards.

The object of the game is to assemble a complete set of cards of one color along with a touchdown card and a field goal card.

The aim of this word game is to find words that fit into a specific topic and comply with either being a "High" or "Low" word. With A=1 and Z=26 every word that you come up with will score you a certain amount of points.
There are 5 topics and and you have a minute to come up with an answer for each, either an answer with as many letters towards the end of the alphabet to score you most points; or a short answer with letters towards the beginning of the alphabet. After the time has run out you go through topic by topic, 
you decide whether you answer is unique, an answer that no-one else has chosen; then you think if your word is the highest or lowest depending on which was chosen at the beginning of the game. If you choose to move onto the "Showdown" you can then text in the number to find out your words score. You can, if your good at maths work out the number yourself. 
The winner of the showdown gets 20 points, if you had a correct answer but didn't go into the showdown you get 10; and if you didn't think that you had a unique answer but it was still a right answer you get 5 points. 
After 5 rounds, totaling 20 minutes you work out your overall score and the winner is the player with the most points.

For decades, peace has reigned Gaia. But now, for no apparent reason, the five kingdoms
powerful of the world have begun a fierce battle to ensure the supremacy of his
race. There is no time for diplomacy is now only time to conquer the world.

Game description

In Conquest of Gaia, each player assumes the role of one of the five kingdoms struggling to establish the supremacy of their race. The players' goal is to get more points than their opponents. To get points is necessary to control territory and build cities or castles in them. He who gets the most points at the end of the game wins the game.

The Capsule Monsters game is a game released by Mattel, based on the Yu-Gi-Oh! Capsule Monsters anime arc, which was partly based on Capsule Monster Chess from early issues of the Yu-Gi-Oh! manga.

The object of the game is to defeat your opponent's King. The first player to reduce their opponent's King's Hit Points to 0 is the winner. The Game has two different levels, the Basic Game for beginners and the Advanced Game for more experienced players.

Little knowledge of the existence of the game became known and production was apparently discontinued after the release of just a two-player Starter Set and one Booster Pack.

Contention is an abstract strategy game for two centering around the theme of containment and usurpation. The players work in tandem to encircle a rapidly growing mass, while at the same time planning their moves to force their opponent into a bad position.

Players take turns placing one of their color stones in any empty space on the board, followed by placing one of the black colored stones in any empty space directly adjacent to another black stone. The first player who is unable to place a black stone is the winner, regardless of whether or not they are able to place one of their color stones.

Great fun, quick playtime (10-15 minutes at the absolute maximum, usually around 3-5 minutes), and challenging, subtle strategies.

Contention is available for free, as a complete print-and-play package including rules, pieces, and board in a single PDF.

It's 'Gold Rush' time again, here in the 21st Century! With the price of gold skyrocketing higher every day, it’s time you got a piece of the action. Round up a few hombre's to compete against and start digging for gold. Get your hands on a few mines and while your at it, jump a few claims from your competitors.

It’s an all out rush to see who can wrangle up one million dollars in gold nuggets first and get them safely to the bank. But watch out! When your dealing with gold, there is always some outlaw lurking around to steal it from you. It’s going to take more than a little luck to finish first in this game.

Game play
Players take turns rolling the dice and moving around the board in hopes of staking claims in one of the five mines available. Once a player obtains a share in a mine he may dig in it, once he lands or passes the ‘mine for gold’ space. When a player mines for gold he draws one of the ‘golden nugget’ cards and records the amount of gold found, on a score sheet.

During the game, the price of gold will fluctuate when players land on the ‘gold rises’ or ‘gold drops’ spaces, causing his gold to be worth more or less throughout the game. He must try to get this gold to the bank while the price of gold is still high, in order to receive cash payment for his gold. He may of course, deposit as much or as little of his gold as he wishes, hoping for higher prices later.

He must be careful though. There are outlaws waiting to steal all un deposited gold from you. Throughout the game, players can jump claims of other players, thus stealing away their shares of mines, preventing them from gaining more gold. The player who manages to get one million cash on hand first will win the game.

Harem is an easy-to-learn card game where you attempt to create the most envied harem in the lands. Players take the role of a Sultan and play gold and gems to eventually buy harem concubines. But watch out for opponents who hire thieves to threaten your treasury. Once in the harem, concubines train in the arts of dancing and seduction and adorn themselves with jewels. The player with the best harem in the end is the winner!

The players try to pull her figures on the quiz fields and answer a questions there or solve a problem. 
Player gets reward chip after correct answer or solved problem
Who first has one chip in each color wins. The tasks are drawing and pantomime, the other pictograms are available for questions on the areas hobby, nature, culture, technology, or conundrums. The player can decide whether to draw task or take pantomime.

name.value: Das grosse KiKa-Quiz für die Vorschule

item.description:
Preschool verison.
This quiz is playable without being able to read, the tasks come from the daily life of children, each card shows the task and three possible solutions. In a turn a player rolls the die, moves and solves the question of a corresponding card. Tasks are: watch closely, listen acutely, recognize and allocate questions, count and compare or which pictures form a new word? The solution chosen is marked by holding the card with two fingers over the solution, if the finger at the back points at the "Schlaumeir", the answer is correct. For a correct answer player receives the card, the player who first has five cards wins the game.

Chili, Briegel and Bernd paddle from island to island looking for treasure. Whoever discovers the right paddle cards can push the raft to the desired island, and take away the plate there, under where he suspects the treasure chest is. Whoever knocks a piece over the raft can not find a treasure. Anyone who discovers a treasure chest can uncover all the tiles of the island, they are all coins, he gets them all. Anyone who discovers a bomb, loses all coins on the island of the pirates, if there is a sand nothing happens. 
If all plates cleared away, the player with the most gold wins.

This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information. Most of the cards also show small illustrations.

The title translates to "Movie Quotes" and the questions are about that topic.

New Imperialism in China is a 3-7 player strategic-level board wargame, simulates the foreign enclaves in China 1900 - 1911.

Each turn represents one year. 
Players play the role of "Great Qing Empire", "Great Japanese Empire", "United States", "British Empire", "French Republic", "Dutch Empire", "Russian Empire", respectively. 
Players control area with supply point to produce army and fleet for further expansion in each turn. Player who controls the most areas on 12th turn wins.

item.description:
Issue game of Wargame Japanese History #11.

A strategic level wargame about unification of Owari Province based on early years of Oda Nobunaga (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oda_Nobunaga).
NB: A "gunki" is a war story (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunki_monogatari).

Players control either Oda clan or Imagawa clan, and challenge to unification of Owari province.
Players can perform multiple actions in single turn based on the funds held.
The winner is determined by victory points from control of castle.

A board game of Flat Green Bowls

Well You Bowled is a board game based on the sport of flat green bowls. The object of the game, as in real bowls, is to get as many of your woods as possible nearre the Jack than your opponent's nearest wood. The game is designed to be played by two teams of up to four players, but may be played in on an individual basis if required. The game is played over a series of "ends".

Each end the jack is set, then each player places a wood along the baseline and declares the intended length, then draws a card from the top of the deck to determine the position of that wood on the rink in relation to the position nominated. If the wood hits another, then the "wick" cards give directions for the two playing pieces. Players may instead of drawing a card to elect to fire. Instead they draw from the fire deck and follow the instructions. Once all players have played their woods, then end is finished, and the end is scored, and another one started. A game is either played to an agreed number of ends or an agreed number of shots (points).

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Scramblitz requires fast thinking and faster fingers. Each player starts with a mat and a set of 16 double-sided tiles. Your objective: be the first player to arrange your tiles to match the puzzle card. The challenge: which sides of your tiles should face up? It takes plenty of flipping, flopping and swapping to win the game.

Crazy creatures abound in this fast-paced, mixed-up matching race! Draw a card to reveal the challenge. Will you need to find the identical creatures within two differently colored frames, or do quick math once you spot the numbers? Race against your opponents to spot it or solve it. The winner keeps the card. Be the first to collect enough cards to spell “Look Look,” and you take the game! Game board is comprised of eight interchangeable frames, making it a new game every time you play. Includes 68 challenge cards. 2 or more players.

item.description:
An abstract strategy game played on a special board. Two players, X and O, take turns placing a bridge between any two of their adjacent pegs not blocked by an existing bridge. The first player to complete a connected chain of bridges between their sides wins. Ties are not possible.

Visavis is a Shannon switching game on the edges and belongs to the same class of connection games as Bridg-It and TwixT (and to some extend Trellis). Even though a trivial winning strategy has been found for Bridg-It (called Connexxions on the server) Visavis consists of a more complex system of overlaid triangular grids that allows richer variety of play, and no winning strategy is known.

Michail Antonow points out that different tactics must be applied when blocking an opponent's rightward path as opposed to a leftward path. The path can be abruptly cut by a single piece in one direction only; in the opposite direction a single bridge will only divert the path and two bridges are needed for a successful block.

The rules state that a bridge can be placed between any two adjacent pegs of the same colour. However since it can never help to place a bridge between the opponent's pegs, then it is assumed that all moves are made between the current player's pegs. This also simplifies the board notation.

item.description:
Nobles from across the land have been called to compete in grand tournaments as the King is looking for a new champion of the realm. This champion will be determined by the Noble who gains the most glory in these grand tournaments.

Knights from across the realm gather to serve these nobles and gain the rewards of riches and glory in their service.

Can you take on the role of one of these Nobles and use the knights that decide to serve you in order to gain the glory needed to be champion of the realm?

The challenge is to collect Knights from the 6 different Event Types included in the game to create a team that will compete against the other Nobles team of knights for glory in the different tournament seasons. Knights cost money and the Nobles only collect a certain amount each tournament season to pay for their knights. The Tournaments are played by Nobles secretly deciding in which order their knights will compete and then by simply turning their cards face down in their hand to create a small deck they begin drawing their cards one at a time off the top of these decks to play against another Noble's knights in individual competition. Points are scored for the Noble with the highest value knight played (six cards will be played against one another in this way) - and 1 glory is gained by the Noble with the most points at the end of that competition.

A Tournament is made up of each Noble in the game plying each other once in a competition like the one described above.

Once the tournament season is over players have to return some knights to their season decks / hire other knights / collect gold / and try to gain more glory in the next Tournament.

The Game ends when one Noble gains enough glory to win the Kings favor, and become champion of the realm.

Take a completed Sudoku and what can you do with it...how about getting a little more use before tossing it into the recycle bin...Sudoku Recycled are a series of pencil and paper games that you can play using a completed Sudoku. Currently, there are 3 different games you can play and all you need is a pencil, a completed Sudoku and the rules to the game you want to play.

There is:

Tic-Tac-Sudoku a simple Tic-Tac-Toe game for 2 players that brings Tic-Tac-Toe to a new level.

Snakedoku a 2-4 player game where you try and make snakes (the longer the better), but your opponents will try and stop you by cutting in front of you with their own snake. This game also has the Mongoose variant and everyone knows snakes don’t like mongooses.

Sudoku Warriors a 2-3 player game where you place you warriors around villages to gain control of their resources. When a battle breaks out you will need the village's resources to win the battle for a Province. Win the required number of Provinces and win the game.

Don't have a completed Sudoku to play on...no problem just make a Pseudoku.

name.value: Berserk: Tactical Card Game – War of Realms

item.description:
In the distant world of Laar, wandering armies led by powerful magicians live a life of battle. For eons they fought for survival in this world, once scorched by fires of the Cataclysm. Now you have the chance to gather your own army and become the maker of your own fate. Perhaps your path will shape the fate of Laar as well...

In fierce battles in Berserk: Tactical Card Game - War of Realms, your life and the lives of your trusted armies will depend on your skill as a strategist and a warlord. And then, when in the heat of battle you forget about your wounds, forget about the future and about the past, you will understand why this is not simply a game. It is Berserk.

Berserk: Tactical Card Game was previously published in Russian as a collectible card game sold in randomized packs. This English edition of the game uses a fixed card format in which the same cards will be available in each standalone game and expansion pack. Two different ready-to-play decks are included in War of Realms, the first release in this new format.

Reimplements:

 Berserk: Trading Card Game

Who Let The Dogs Out (TM) is a new board game for all the family. The objective is to round up your four escaped dogs and get them back in your house with a bone for each. Remember - my doggie won't stay in if he don't have no bone.

The square game board is divided diagonally into four backyards, with a small house located in the middle of each edge of the board. The game commences with one of each players dogs placed on a marked starting position in each players backyard. Players then use game cards to move one or more dogs directly or to pick up sausages and/or bones to move their own dogs strategically towards, and eventually into, their own home. The first player to get all of their dogs into their house with a bone wins.

imd-spelet is an abstract game, but with a loose word description, or rather inspiration of todays internet usage.

The game-play is based on placing and moving tiles according to dice throws, the goal is to catch the opponent's tiles. It use four tiles as two sided dice with the values 0 or 1 to create binary numbers. The dice are thrown in a decided order to create a number between 0000 = 0 to 1111 = 15.

The game is published as the cover of an educational catalog connected to the IT, media and design (imd)-program at Södertörn University, Stockholm, Sweden.

Farkle Frenzy adds an exciting new dimension to the classic Farkle dice game! As with traditional Farkle, players roll 6 dice, remove only the dice you want to use for points, then re-roll the remaining dice. Press down the funky Bubble Hub to vibrate and bounce the common die, and then let the fun begin! Take a risk and roll to collect scoring dice on the stepped Dice Risers, and race to fill yours first!
For 2 to 4 Players
Ages 8 & Up

Quiz game on the subject of horses, with puzzles and poster, questions from the categories horse and humans, riding and sport, horse mannerisms, horses’ bodies, knowledge and horse breeds. The arrow is turned for the category, correct answers earn a puzzle part, one can place a tip for answers on other player’s questions and earn irons which can be changed into puzzle parts. The first player to complete his puzzle wins the game.

On 32 cards there are 2 questions with three answers each, on the back with information and illustration on the subject. Players receive questions cards, in case of 3 and 4 players also betting cards.

The active player is asked by the quizmaster, if the first answer is right, he is asked the second question. If the answer is again correct, the player receives the card and places it with his betting cards. In case the first answer was wrong the left neighbour of the player can risk an answer and use one of his betting cards. If he answers wrong, he loses he card. When no one has questions cards left, the player with the most betting cards wins.

"The world of stars" in English
On 32 cards there are 2 questions with three answers each, on the back with information and illustration on the subject. Players receive questions cards, in case of 3 and 4 players also betting cards.

The active player is asked by the quizmaster, if the first answer is right, he is asked the second question. If the answer is again correct, the player receives the card and places it with his betting cards. In case the first answer was wrong the left neighbour of the player can risk an answer and use one of his betting cards. If he answers wrong, he loses he card. When no one has questions cards left, the player with the most betting cards wins.

"The world of technology" in English
On 32 cards there are 2 questions with three answers each, on the back with information and illustration on the subject. Players receive questions cards, in case of 3 and 4 players also betting cards.

The active player is asked by the quizmaster, if the first answer is right, he is asked the second question. If the answer is again correct, the player receives the card and places it with his betting cards. In case the first answer was wrong the left neighbour of the player can risk an answer and use one of his betting cards. If he answers wrong, he loses he card. When no one has questions cards left, the player with the most betting cards wins.

Players are journalists and travel round the world to collect interesting material and pictures for a new issue of GEOlino. One either moves the journalist and takes a round tile, takes a text tile or take an airline-ticket. 3 round or 3 white tiles on one subject result in a conference: A theme disk is laid out, all players bid on correct answers, for correct guesses players receive square pages for their issue. Complete magazines are scored for articles matching the title page, advertising and longest consecutive article on one subject, the player with the highest score wins the game.

Koins is a simple and engaging game for three players.

The players all start out with a handful of coins. Each turn, the players bet one or more of their coins, the bets are called "hands".
If all hands are different, the middle hand is the winner (ex. 5 out of 2, 5, 7).
If two hands are the same, the third hand is the winner (ex. 2 out of 5, 5, 2).
If all hands are the same, there is no winner and the coins are put into the pool.

The player with the winning hand takes all the coins that were bet that turn, as well as the pool if there is any, and a new round is played.

32 cards show 2 questions with 3 answers each, on the backside information and illustrations on the subject are given. Players receive quest cards and betting cards for 3 and 4 players. The quiz master poses a question to his neighbour, in case of a correct answer also the second questions - if both are correct the candidate receives the card. If the first answer is wrong, the neighbour of the candidate can risk a betting card and try to answer. If he answers wrong, he loses the card. If nobody has cards left, the player with the most betting cards wins.

"Our bodies quiz game" in English
32 cards show 2 questions with 3 answers each, on the backside information and illustrations on the subject are given. Players receive quest cards and betting cards for 3 and 4 players. The quiz master poses a question to his neighbour, in case of a correct answer also the second questions – if both are correct the candidate receives the card. If the first answer is wrong, the neighbour of the candidate can risk a betting card and try to answer. If he answers wrong, he loses the card. If nobody has cards left, the player with the most betting cards wins.

Dinosaurs themed quiz-game.
32 cards show 2 questions with three answers each, the back side shows information and illustration on the subject. Players have question cards and betting cards, the starting player chooses a card and the candidate on his left tries to answer the first question - if he is right, the second is asked. In case of two correct answers the candidate receives the card and puts it with his betting cards. If the first answer is wrong, the left neighbour of the candidate can take over by betting one of his betting cards - if he answers wrong he loses the card. At the end the player with the most cards wins.

The game of MATCHET is played with 36 triangle shaped pieces. These pieces are tri-colored and have numbers from 1 to 10 at their points. The object of the game is to match the colors and numbers in multiples of 5, First person to get rid of all his triangles is the winner.

"Aviation and aerospace" in English
32 cards show 2 questions with three answers each, the back side shows information and illustration on the subject. Players have question cards and risk cards, the starting player chooses a card and the candidate on his left tries to answer the first question - if he is right, the second is asked. In case of two correct answers the candidate receives the card and puts it with his risk cards. If the first answer is wrong, the left neighbour of the candidate can take over by risking one of his risk cards - if he answers wrong he loses the card. At the end the player with the most cards wins.

"Planetary & Space Quiz Game" in English

32 cards show 2 questions with 3 answers each, on the backside information and illustrations on the subject are given. Players receive quest cards and betting cards for 3 and 4 players. The quiz master poses a question to his neighbour, in case of a correct answer also the second questions – if both are correct the candidate receives the card. If the first answer is wrong, the neighbour of the candidate can risk a betting card and try to answer. If he answers wrong, he loses the card. If nobody has cards left, the player with the most betting cards wins.

"Knights & Castles quiz game" in English

32 cards show 2 questions with three answers each, the back side shows information and illustration on the subject. Players have question cards and risk cards, the starting player chooses a card and the candidate on his left tries to answer the first question - if he is right, the second is asked. In case of two correct answers the candidate receives the card and puts it with his risk cards. If the first answer is wrong, the left neighbour of the candidate can take over by risking one of his risk cards - if he answers wrong he loses the card. At the end the player with the most cards wins.

"Our Earth Quiz Game" in English

32 cards show 2 questions with three answers each, the back side shows information and illustration on the subject. Players have question cards and risk cards, the starting player chooses a card and the candidate on his left tries to answer the first question - if he is right, the second is asked. In case of two correct answers the candidate receives the card and puts it with his risk cards. If the first answer is wrong, the left neighbour of the candidate can take over by risking one of his risk cards - if he answers wrong he loses the card. At the end the player with the most cards wins.

Two parts are combined into a complete photo. The first player to gather 12 parts that is 6 complete pictures, one from each category, wins the game. In his turn a player rolls the die and moves the butterfly: On a sunflower, trefoil or poppy spot a question must be answered by the active player, in some cases the other players can place a tip for the correct answer. The correct answer earns the active player a picture part or a trefoil, for a correct tip one receives a trefoil. Four trefoils can be exchanged for a picture part.

A memory game that teaches you French.

Memory Mate uses simple object matching to improve your child's concentration. Trying to remember where the pig, dog and chicken are hiding is a fun way to hone memory skills - all-important building blocks of learning!

A pair of puzzle cards match by picture and fit, one puzzle card as the English word and the other the word in Spanish.

Spread out all the cards facedown on a large flat surface. On your turn, flip over two cards to try to make a picture match.

If you match a pair, fit them side-by-side and say the name of the object shown in English and French. Keep the pair and try again for another match by turning over two new cards.

If the two cards picked don't match, your turn is over. Flip the cards facedown and try to remember where they are for next time.

Players alternate turns and continue to match until no cards remain. The winner is the player with the most pairs.

item.description:
Kuku is a Polish traditional card game for two or more players. It's slightly modified version of Kemps.

It is played with standard deck of 52 cards. Each player is dealt a hand of 3 cards, but one player is dealt a hand of 4 cards. The rest of cards are irrelevant. If any player has three cards in the same color or value he says "kuku!" and wins. After dealing the player with 4 cards gives one of his cards to the player on his left. One card (not necessarily the same) is going around until one of the players has three cards in the same color or value.

Six ways to play! Learn shapes, colors, animals, beginning letter sounds, counting and addition!

Object: Be the first player to shout "BINGO" by getting 4-in-a-row.

Game One: Color/Shape Match
Use the spinner, and cards with shapes on them. The youngest player begins by spinning the spinner and calling out the shape and color to which the arrow points. For example, "Blue Star!". Then all players search their cards for that color and shape. If they have a match, they cover it with a Tad bingo chip. Play continues clockwise with each player taking a turn spinning and calling. For shorter games, just match colors or just match shapes.

Game Two: Number Match
Use the spinner, and cards with numbers on them. The youngest player begins by spinning the spinner and calling out the number to which the arrow points. For example, "number 9!". Then all players search their cards for that number. If they have a match, they cover it with a Tad bingo chip. Play continues clockwise with each player taking a turn spinning and calling.

Game Three: Animal Match
Use the spinner, and cards with animals on them. The youngest player begins by spinning the spinner and calling out the animal and color to which the arrow points. For example, "Purple Lion!". Then all players search their cards for that color and animal. If they have a match, they cover it with a Tad bingo chip. Play continues clockwise with each player taking a turn spinning and calling. For shorter games, just match animals. Or for a beginning letter challenge, instead of announcing the animal the caller says "the animal that begins with M". Players then place Tad bingo chips on ALL animals on their cards that begin with M.

Game Four: Add-Up and Match
Use the spinner with the addition equations, and cards with numbers on them. The youngest player begins by spinning the spinner and solves the equation to which the arrow points and calls out the answer. For example, if the spinner points to 9+1, then the player solves it and calls out 10. Then all players search for 10 and cover it with a Tad bingo chip. Play continues clockwise with each player taking a turn spinning and calling.

Winning:
A player wins when they get 4 Tad bingo chips in a horizontal, vertical, or diagonal row and they shout out "bingo".

item.description: On the board in four parts schools of fish and corals can be found in varying numbers and colours. Colour die, dot die und symbol die together result in a combination of three characteristics which players should find on the board. The board is variable and thus always new situations form. A player discovering the combination wanted shows it and marks it with a chip. If a combination has already been covered, the chip goes to the treasure chest. If an octopus is rolled, all chips from the board are put on the chest. If the chest is rolled the chips from the chest are distributed among the other players. The player placing his last chip wins the game.

The game comprises 110 cards with 220 situations taken from daily life. Each card describes the situation and suggests three different ways of behaviour, only one way is the correct one. Players roll the die and move their pawn, the end spot of the move determines what happens: On an empty spot they stop or buy another move with 3 Chips. On a "Benimm ist in" spot one draws a card and answers the question. A correct answer is rewarded with a chip. On the red "live"-spots one must enact the situation pictured on the board, the other players act as jury. Wrong answers send the player back 3 spots. The first player to reach the finish wins the game.

Players start at the castle door and try to reach the tower, they have to pass 29 spaces and overcome ghosts. Good dice rolls and clever use of the results will help a player to be there first and win. In his turn a player rolls all 3 dice: To enter a spot a dice in the roll must show the number of the space or it must be possible to form the number from the numbers rolled. When the dice have fallen accordingly, one can enter several spots in sequence. If helmet and armour are rolled at the same time, one can move to the next armour chip. All players not in first place may re-roll one die per turn.

6.000 questions in three difficulties, the themes are technology, politics, sky & earth, history, nature, art and culture, sports and fun and general, players try to reach the golden finish spot as quickly as possible by answering questions in the colour-coded difficulty range their piece stands in. Correct answers allow movement, themes are determined by roll of the die.

The 36 Good Night tiles show 6 times activities necessary before going to bed. Each player tries to be the first to collect one motif each. In his turn he rolls the colour die and moves to the next spot in this colour, on a Sandman spot he can turn over a tile and take it if he has not got the motif yet. On the purple corner spots one has to give back the motif shown. Older children can play with the number die, then the "6" sends a player to the purple corner spot.

The game board shows an Indian camp in full swing, each player tries to find 8 tiles corresponding to his theme tile from a total of 48 tiles, colour coding makes it easier to spot fitting tiles. In his turn a player can turn up as many tiles as he wants - if "Überfall" is turned up the move ends and he receives no tiles. If he ends his move voluntarily he can keep all tiles corresponding to his theme. The first player who has found all 8 tiles can lay out all tiles on the board, ends the game and wins.

Ost ! is a medieval skirmish miniature wargame, originally published in Vae Victis magazine issue #32.

The game uses a simple chit-pull system (using common playing cards) to alternate minis activation between players. Each activated figure has 2 actions, which can be used to move, fight, fire, reload a weapon or perform a special action (such as climbing on horseback). Combat is resolved by an opposed d10 roll with modifiers (for fighters skill, armor, weapons...), ranged combat by a die roll on a table.

The game includes rules for ranged weapons, cover, armor, horse riding, morale, civilians and a scenario ("Les routiers sont sympas").

Scale: 1 mini = 1 man, 1 cm = 1 m, a turn = a few seconds

item.description:
User Summary

Alphabet Land is a simple boardgame intended for young audiences (recommended ages 4-8). Players use a spinner to travel around the board collecting letters of the alphabet, which are associated with particular spaces. The spaces are shown as balloons. Landing on a space with a letter on it allows the player to collect that letter. Landing on a black balloon allows a player to take a letter from anywhere on the board. Landing on a purpler balloon allows the player to steal a letter from another player. A player is "stung" and must return a card to the board if he or she lands on a spot showing the Alpha-Bee.

The game ends when a player lands on the Finish spot with an exact spin. At that point all players count up there cards. The player with the most cards wins.

This title appears to take some inspiration from Candyland.

The Enemy is attacking your borders and you must withstand the three waves of invasion heading your way.
You must choose and deploy your units to destroy the Invader before it eliminates them all.
This dice game is a solo version of co-ordinate based battle games, like Battleships or Salvo.

You choose which Units to use - Bunkers, Guns, Tanks and Command. Then deploy them on the grid to outlast the attack of the Invader.

Near misses result in bombardments that cover multiple grid points, so a well thought out deployment is essential.

You need to survive three waves of attack to win the game.

The ducklings race around the pond, but to make it more difficult each must find three items before moving. In his turn a player rolls the die and may move the number of spots rolled when he can find two more tiles showing the same item as the tile under the marker stone. He may turn over up to three tiles, if he finds two correct tiles he moves his duck, if not, can only move the marker to another tile. Je first player round the pond and back at the duck house wins the game.

On the board fairy tale pictures are connected by moss hills with and without arrows, forming a circuit. Each player starts on any of the story spots, 24 story tiles are laid out face down. In his turn a player rolls the die and moves the number of spots rolled. If he reaches a moss hill, the turn ends. On a moss hill with an arrow he can turn up a tile and replace it face down. On a story spot he can turn up a tile and keep it if it corresponds to the story of the spot, and he has another turn. When all tiles are taken up, the player with the most tiles wins.

Honouring the Mozart Year 2006 Noris offers a quiz game with 1320 questions and answers on the subject of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. Players move their tokens over a historic map of Europe, following in the steps of Mozart. Each player at the beginning of the game receives several cities visited by Mozart during his travels and have now to visit those cities, too. To continue travelling a player must correctly answer a question. The first player to arrive back in Salzburg has won the game.

The "word crocodile" gobbles up all words it finds in its path, but cannot digest them and gives them back again letter by letter. A non-playing referee slides a card into the crocodile. At the beginning only the tip of the crocodile’s tongue is visible and the first letter of the word. Now all players guess which word the crocodile is spitting out and call out words. Each player may only call out one word for each new letter, if you call out more than once you are disqualified for this word. If somebody manages to guess correctly, the card is shown to all players and is given to this player. The referee enters a new card. If the word was not guessed correctly after the first letter, the next letter is slid out and all guess again. If you do not want to guess you need not do so. If the word is not guessed before the last letter appears the card goes to the player who reads out the complete word first.

At the end of the word a little picture clarifies and explains the meaning of the word and allows control if the guess was correct. The playing time can be varied by the number of cards used. When all cards have been played, the winner is the player who collected the majority of cards.

The time robbers have stolen the hands of all the clocks, but the children can repair the damage and position the hands again. The cards are stacked hand-free clocks facing upwards. The bottom card is drawn, the picture on each card gives hints to the time-frame: A soup pot indicates lunchtime, a sleeping child night-time. You try to position the hands on the big clock as exactly as possible. The backside of the card shows the correct time - if you did it correctly, you receive the card. With 5 cards you win the game.

Third of the Spielbox Wallace Edition Games.

Barbarians invade the crumbling Roman Empire. Once they reach Rome or when the last coin has been taken from the board the game ends. Whoever held on to the most provinces on the board wins the game.

To start, every player places his pieces on provinces on the map, every province gets a coin as well. Possible actions per round are determined by throwing 3 dice per player, then placing a chit of this player in the corresponding box. Once every player has rolled and placed his chits the actions are taken, starting with the 1 box up to the 6 box. For every chit in the box one appropriate action is taken by that player.

1, 3 and 5 is a barbarian attack, 2 and 4 allows a player to attack, 6 is taxation.
Attacks are resolved by throwing 3 dice, any double causes one hit and eliminates the defending piece, a triple allows for a barbarian breakthrough and eliminates another piece adjacent to the original defender. Taxation allows for a maximum of three coins taken from the board.

item.description:
Players are dealt 12, 10 or 8 cards depending on the number of players. The cards are three types - Land cards, Goods cards and Choice cards (which act as jokers).
The game plays a little like Rummy as players have to collect sets which are laid in front of them. You can add to your sets and you can add to opponents' sets.
The sets within the card types consist of a Question and related answers so a little trivia knowledge helps you not to overlook cards you need.
Winner is the one who plays all their cards first.

name.value: Fragst Du mich ,,, neck ich dich

item.description:
Card game which is a question and answer game for children.
All the cards are dealt out. Now the first player asks the person to the left of him or her (your neighbour in other words) a question. If they get the answer right, they get the card. If the answer was wrong, the questioner gets to keep it and it goes back into their hand. Now your left hand neighbour asks a question of his or her neighbour, and so on.
The one who gets the most answers right wins. Limited replayability I would think.

Goblins, Inc. is a corporation dedicated to building unstoppable giant doomsday robots, and it's looking for a new Boss. Do you have what it takes?

Team up with your greed-driven fellow goblins and build the ultimate doomsday robot. Meet other teams in epic battles and blow them up, but always remember, only one goblin can win because there is no "G" in team work!

The game plays over two rounds in which you partner up with each of your fellow players to try to build the ultimate giant doomsday robot – but the other players don't know which hidden agendas you must complete to impress the Boss! During the four phases of the round, the teams take turns designing, building and piloting their robots in order to destroy the other team and get one step closer to becoming the next Boss of Goblins, Inc.

item.description:
One treasure is hidden under each tree in the forest. As you move from tree to tree, you get to peek at the treasures you find. Can you remember where each one is hidden? When the king asks where one of the treasures is, players race to reach the castle with the right information.

Playable with only 2-4 players, Sagaland Mini is the smaller brother, the travel version of Spiel des Jahres-winning Sagaland (Enchanted Forest) with only 7 trees, 7 cards and a board consisting of fewer spaces.

Re-implements:

 Enchanted Forest

item.description: The village pond has frozen over and many people enjoy a lovely winter’s day, and so do the players. They slide across the ice and collect tiles for hot chocolate or gingerbread. If you have found three identical tiles you swap them at the corresponding booth for a golden victory point tile. In your turn you roll two dice and move in two different direction, but not to and fro, for each direction you use the result of one die. If you reach a tile and do not want to take it you turn it up, open tiles are covered again. If you take a tile you replace it with one from the bag, and your turn ends. Action tiles you pick up you can use in your next turn. When two booths are empty, you win with the highest score from your victory point tiles.

A dice game to accompany children through the year, in play they learn the 12 months with a typical situation for each month. The children learn the sequence of the months and can allocate the seasons with the help of the coloured bottom strips. Aim of the game is to collect as many month discs as possible, a player who places a disc on the correct month receives the disc.

Players try to caper the most valuable treasures from each other and try to have the biggest treasure at the end. Ships are loaded with 8 chests showing dice tots from 2-5, the surplus chests are flotsam. In his turn a player rolls the die and takes a corresponding chest from a player or from the flotsam. For a cannon the bottom card of a ship can be turned over and the treasure taken when there is only one treasure left on the card. When the last card of a ship is sunk, the player with the most treasure cards wins, mice are valueless.

Question and answer card game for adults only. The risquè cards are shuffled and placed in the centre of the table. In your turn you draw the top card and ask another player the question, hoping to embarrass him or her. The most correct answers wins the game
Players criss-cross through Austria, amassing cards as they get to certain cities. The first to visit a pre-agreed number of cities, wins

I expect this was a promotional game issued by the tourist board of the Salzkammergut region in Austria. Players criss-cross on a map of the region, answering questions about the places they find. Thus it would be an educational game as well as a tourist game.
First to reach home is the winner.

International Tennis simulates a professional singles tennis game. Play is card-driven: the server draws a serve card to determine where the serve goes (after the receiver chooses a court position), if the receiver returns the serve a return card is drawn, if the server returns a rally card is drawn, etc. Tracks are provided for game, set, and match scoring.

Billions of years ago, when the earth was just an incandescent globe that began to cool - big masses of rocks and ores, that were before in a liquid state, started to solidify, creating what we call today a terrestrial crust. The magma, still boiling and liquid, started big waves around an unstable soil and this huge rock layers collided and rose from the soil, creating the mountains. In the abstract game YN a player will experience the idea of creating these mountain rages using sequences of dices in a scenario that simulates the Earth at its formation process. The player with less numbers in the dices outside the board wins the game.

Each player have a bunch of dice (that represents mountains) and need to put in the board, but there's a problem: a dice only can touch another dice with a same value like a domino mechanic and after each turn a player can put a small token to create blockades to the opponent. The objective of the game is to be the player with few numbers in the dices out of the board.

item.description:
Quinella is a game that brings you the excitement of the racetrack.

Players bet on which of 4 horses will win the race. The horses are represented by the suits of a standard deck of cards: Heart, Diamond, Spade and Club. Each round one player acts as the caller, dealing cards to determine the odds. Bets are placed using chips. When all bets are placed the caller deals cards to move the horses. When the race is over the caller pays out the winning bets. The player to the left of the caller is the caller for the next round. The winner is the player who finishes with the most chips.

How could that have happened? Black Stories are fiddly, morbid and mysterious riddles for teenagers and adults. The players try to reconstruct the crime by asking, guessing and fiddling about. Only yes/no answers are allowed. A spooky card game just right for any party.

As in the first 6 editions you have to ask yes or no questions. So you could find the black humor solution.

It's a perfect party game for big rounds, but also playable with 2 players.

item.description:
The object of the game is to have all your pawns arrive to the home squares of the same colour, located at the end of the course, before to the other players.

At start of the game, each player place 1 pawn at START box and 3 pawns on the boxes of his colour.

Each player rolls a dice and move only one pawn according to the result. In case of 6, player could move and re-roll, moving another pawn, or free one pawn placing it on START box.

If one pawn finish its moving on a box occupied by another pawn, this pawn will return on START box.

This is a game based on the TV show Winx Club and is meant for ages 4 and up.

Game has 3 levels: easy, medium and "difficult".

The aim of the game is to be the first to dress, make-up etc. for the Court ball of the evening.

Players roll the dice, enter in a room (i.e. dressing room) and take a card and resolve event, or complete a set of cards in order to dress and prepare her Winx for the Court ball.

name.value: Game of Flags of the United Nations

item.description:
Info on this game gathered from the ELLIOTT AVEDON
VIRTUAL MUSEUM OF GAMES.

This is a Card game. There are 40 cards in the deck.

The set of 40 cards shows the flags of the United Nations. They are divided into 12 categories, mostly geographic as follows:
 •1 United Nations UN
•5 Veto Countries VC
 •5 South American Countries SAC
 •3 Central American Countries CAC
 •3 Island Countries
 •2 Scandinavian Countries SC
 •2 African Countries AC
•3 Emblem Countries EC
•4 Moslem Countries MC
•3 Picture Countries PC
•3 Costume Countries CC
•6 Other Countries
 The object of the game is to get and meld complete categories (see above list). With two people playing, deal 9 cards to each, three playing, 8 cards, and four playing 7 cards. Place remainder of pack face down in center of table and turn over the top card to start the face up stack. Player at dealer’s left starts by drawing a card from either stack, or by calling for a card from some other player. He must have at least one of the cards in the category for which he is calling. If successful he may call again from the same person until unsuccessful and then must discard one card on face up stack, which completes his turn. Then, the next player to left follows the same procedure.

Complete categories, and meld them, face up, in front of you as fast as possible. A player may pick up all the cards in the face up stack at any turn, but must meld at least one complete category after so doing. You must meld at least two categories before you can meld the single UN card. When any player has no cards left after his discard - the hand ends, and he scores a bonus of 100 for going out. Cards held by other players are discarded for next deal and each scores the total of the value of each card in their meld. Play for time available - highest score wins.

Card game. First separate the Mammi cards from the rest. The Mammi cards are stacked face down on the table. The rest of the cards are the Little Negro cards and are stacked nearby. Each player gets three Little Negro cards, and one Mammi card is revealed.

In his turn, a player first looks to see if he has Little Negro cards that total 10 or more and match the colour of the revealed Mammi card. If so, he takes the Mammi card. If not, he draws a new Little Negro card and discards one.

The game ends when the Mammi cards run out, and the winner is the player with the most Mammi cards.

Player crawl into a dungeon and try to get hand on mercenarys, golds and precious information about some Quest to mark points and win the game.
Each turn; the player have two choice.
Try to win room (where mercenary,golds and information are)
To do so, the player put face down one of is INITIATIVE counter on the appropriat card.Each player get 7 INITIATIVE counters (0-1-1-2-3-4-5) After, next player decide if i try to get the same room or Explore new one.
if he decide to explore new one, he must put one of is INITIATIVE counter on the new explored room. 
When all player have play all is INITIATIVE counter the room was resolve one at time left from right.
Firts, return face up any INITIATIVE counter and countthe result. The player whit more INI win the room and resolve any event on room (if some) then take all supply listed on that room.
At the end, the player with the most information point and dead monstrers win the game

Thankfully Flying Cheese does not challenge players to shoot cheese into one another's mouths – but you will be launching "cheese" skyward to try to land it in your mouse home.

Each round starts with players laying their home tiles (4, 6 or 8 depending on the number of players) and 1-2 cat tiles one by one in the 25 slots in the game tray. The center is reserved for a 2-4 point tile, depending on the round.

Once everyone has placed their home and cat tiles, players take turns launching the cheese dice into the tray using their spoon-shaped catapults. Players have two chances to try to land a cheese die in the tray. If they land on a home tile, the owner of that tile earns one point immediately. Landing on a cat costs the player one point, while hitting the center tile earns 2-4 points. Land off the board or in an empty slot, and you get nothing.

After all twelve cheese dice have been launched, tally the face-up dots on each player's home tiles; each die has three blank faces and 1-2 dots on the other faces. The player with the largest total earns two additional points.

Flying Cheese lasts three rounds, and the player with the most points after three rounds wins.

In Isegrim, players are trying to collect a certain set of cards in order to win – but they don't even necessarily know what they're holding!

The deck in Isegrim consists of fifty double-sided cards, with each side of a card showing one of five animals in one of five landscapes. Each player starts the game with seven cards in hand, with a circle of fifteen cards laid out in a circle on the table. Players then exchange cards based on questions and answers between one another, trying to lead others down false paths while collecting the cards one needs in order to win.
